title: The Role of Accountants and Accounting Information

slides.title: The Accountant's Crucial Role
content: Accountants gather, analyze, and communicate financial data; which is vital for internal and external stakeholders.
They assess a firm's financial strengths and manage risks, ensuring accuracy and transparency.
Accountants maintain records of taxes paid, income received, and all expenses incurred.
Forensic accountants use accounting knowledge for investigations of financial wrongdoings.
Accounting profession helps maintain public trust in financial markets and business institutions.
slides.script: Welcome to Chapter 15: The Role of Accountants and Accounting Information. In this chapter, we will look at the critical functions accountants perform in business, beyond just crunching numbers. We will look at their role as investigators, gatekeepers, and providers of valuable insights to internal and external stakeholders alike. We will also examine the key financial statements that accountants prepare and their ethical responsibilities.

slides.title: Financial vs. Managerial Accounting
content: Financial accounting serves external users. Examples of external users include investors, creditors, and regulatory bodies.
Financial accounting follows GAAP standards to create standardized reports for outside stakeholders.
Managerial accounting serves internal users. Examples of internal users include management team and department leaders.
Managerial accounting provides tailored information to support internal decision-making and planning.
slides.script: This slide distinguishes between the two major branches of accounting: financial and managerial. Financial accounting focuses on providing information to external stakeholders like investors and regulators, adhering to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles, or GAAP. Managerial accounting, on the other hand, provides tailored information to internal users, such as managers, to support their decision-making.

slides.title: Types of Accounting Professionals
content: Certified Public Accountants (CPAs) are licensed professionals providing services to the public.
CPAs perform audits, tax preparation, and management consulting.
Private accountants are salaried employees working within specific companies.
Forensic accountants investigate financial irregularities and assist in litigation.
Management accountants support managers in various business activities.
slides.script: This slide introduces the different types of accounting professionals. Certified Public Accountants, or CPAs, are licensed and provide services to the public. Private accountants work within companies, and management accountants focus on supporting internal decision-making. Forensic accountants are the detectives of the accounting world, investigating financial wrongdoings.

slides.title: Federal Regulations: Sarbanes-Oxley (SOX)
content: Sarbanes-Oxley (SOX) Act was passed in 2002 to restore public trust.
SOX restricts non-audit services CPAs can offer clients, ensuring independence.
CEOs and CFOs must personally certify the accuracy of financial reports.
Companies must establish systems for anonymous reporting of unethical practices.
Sarbox imposes criminal penalties for falsifying records or defrauding shareholders.
slides.script: This slide focuses on the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, also known as SOX, a crucial piece of legislation passed in response to major accounting scandals. SOX aims to restore public trust by imposing strict requirements on financial reporting and auditor independence. It holds CEOs and CFOs personally responsible for the accuracy of financial statements and requires companies to have systems for anonymous reporting of unethical practices.

slides.title: The Accounting Equation: The Foundation
content: The accounting equation states: Assets = Liabilities + Owners' Equity.
This equation must always balance after every transaction, ensuring accuracy.
Assets are economic resources expected to benefit the firm, including cash, inventory, and equipment.
Liabilities are debts owed to outside parties, such as suppliers and lenders.
Owners' Equity represents the owners' stake in the company after liabilities are paid.
slides.script: This slide presents the fundamental accounting equation: Assets equal Liabilities plus Owners' Equity. This equation forms the basis of all accounting transactions. Assets are what the company owns, Liabilities are what it owes, and Owners' Equity represents the owners' stake in the company.

slides.title: Financial Statements: Overview
content: Financial statements summarize a firm's financial status for stakeholders.
Balance sheets show a firm's financial condition at a specific point in time.
Income statements show a firm's revenues and expenses over a period of time.
Statements of cash flows summarize a firm's cash receipts and payments.
slides.script: This slide gives an overview of the three core financial statements: the Balance Sheet, the Income Statement, and the Statement of Cash Flows. We will look into each one in more detail on the following slides.

slides.title: The Balance Sheet: A Snapshot
content: The balance sheet provides a snapshot of a firm’s financial condition at a specific point in time.
Assets are categorized as current, fixed, and intangible.
Liabilities are categorized as current and long-term.
Owners' Equity is divided into paid-in capital and retained earnings.
Assets must always equal Liabilities plus Owners’ Equity.
slides.script: The Balance Sheet provides a snapshot of what a company owns and owes at a particular point in time. Assets are listed on one side, categorized as current, fixed, and intangible. Liabilities are listed on the other side, categorized as current and long-term. The difference between assets and liabilities is Owner's Equity. Crucially, the Balance Sheet always adheres to the Accounting Equation: Assets must equal Liabilities plus Owner's Equity.

slides.title: The Income Statement: Performance Summary
content: The income statement reports revenues and expenses over a period of time, such as a year.
It calculates a firm's profit or loss (net income).
Key components include revenues, cost of revenues, operating expenses, and net income.
Gross Profit is calculated by subtracting Cost of Revenues from Total Revenues.
Operating Income is calculated by subtracting Operating Expenses from Gross Profit.
slides.script: The Income Statement shows a company's financial performance over a specific period of time. It begins with revenues and then subtracts costs and expenses to arrive at Net Income, which is the bottom line. The Income Statement provides key insights into a company's profitability.

slides.title: Statement of Cash Flows: Money In, Money Out
content: The statement of cash flows summarizes cash receipts and payments over a period of time.
It details cash flows from operating, investing, and financing activities.
Operating activities include buying and selling goods and services.
Investing activities include buying and selling assets like stocks, bonds and property.
Financing activities include borrowing or repaying debt, issuing stock, and paying dividends.
slides.script: The Statement of Cash Flows summarizes the movement of cash both into and out of a company. It categorizes these cash flows into three main activities: operating, investing, and financing. It helps assess a company's ability to generate cash and meet its short-term and long-term obligations.

slides.title: Budgets: Internal Financial Statements
content: A budget is a detailed report on estimated receipts and expenditures for a future period.
Budgets are used for internal planning, controlling, and decision-making.
They guide resource allocation and help assess financial performance.
Budgets are typically created for a year, with longer-term (3-5 year) budgets for significant expenditures.
slides.script: This slide introduces the Budget, a crucial internal financial statement. Budgets are detailed reports on estimated receipts and expenditures for a future period, typically a year. They serve as a roadmap for planning, controlling, and making decisions within the company.

slides.title: Reporting Standards: GAAP and More
content: GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Principles) are standards governing financial reports.
They ensure consistent and dependable financial information for external users.
GAAP require proper revenue recognition and full disclosure for accurate reporting.
Ethical violations of GAAP can lead to serious legal and financial repercussions.
The IASB seeks to establish consistent accounting practices globally.
slides.script: This slide explains the importance of reporting standards. GAAP, or Generally Accepted Accounting Principles, are the guidelines governing financial reports, ensuring consistency and reliability. They require proper revenue recognition and full disclosure. Violations of GAAP can lead to severe consequences. The International Accounting Standards Board, or IASB, is working to establish consistent accounting practices globally.

slides.title: Analyzing Financial Statements with Ratios
content: Financial statements provide data for ratio analysis, aiding stakeholder decision-making.
Solvency ratios assess a firm's ability to repay debt, indicating its risk.
Profitability ratios measure a firm's earning power for owners.
Activity ratios evaluate management's efficiency in using a firm's resources.
slides.script: Financial statements provide a wealth of data, but to make sense of it all, we use ratio analysis. This slide highlights some key financial ratios, grouped into three categories: solvency, profitability, and activity. Each category provides insights into different aspects of a company's financial health and can aid stakeholders in making informed decisions.

slides.title: Ethics in Accounting: A Foundation of Trust
content: Ethics is paramount in accounting, maintaining public trust in business institutions.
AICPA's Code of Professional Conduct guides ethical behavior for CPAs.
The code emphasizes responsibilities, public interest, integrity, objectivity, and due care.
Violations of accounting ethics can erode public trust and lead to severe consequences.
slides.script: Ethics play a crucial role in accounting. The AICPA's Code of Professional Conduct provides ethical guidelines for CPAs, emphasizing responsibilities, public interest, integrity, and due care. Ethical violations can have devastating consequences for businesses and the accounting profession as a whole.

slides.title: International Accounting Standards Board (IASB)
content: The IASB (International Accounting Standards Board) develops global accounting standards.
The goal is consistency in financial reporting for global comparisons.
Over 100 countries have adopted IASB accounting practices.
The USA is working toward convergence with IASB.
slides.script: Finally, this slide introduces the International Accounting Standards Board, or IASB. This organization aims to create a set of global accounting standards to promote consistency and comparability in financial reporting across different countries. This is especially important in today's globalized economy. Thank you. This concludes Chapter 15. Please refer to the exercises and cases at the end of the chapter to further enhance your understanding of accounting's important role in business.
